abstract.text: Use touch input and virtual controllers to make your game available to players without controllers.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Adding touch controls to games that support game controllers in iOS

inlineContent.text: Many people play games on iOS devices without using a physical controller. You can make your game available to them by adding touch controls, even if you designed your game for a physical controller. The
class leverages the Game Controller framework and optionally provides a default user interface.
can also render custom controls.

content.text: Create a custom view controller subclass

inlineContent.text: A Metal-based game typically presents content in a
. An instance of
, known as the root view controller, manages the
. Your root view controller is responsible for the
instance. To take responsibility, subclass from
rather than
If your game supports tvOS, you need to subclass from
To create a custom subclass of

, create a new file in your project using the Cocoa Touch Class template. In the “Subclass of” combination box, enter “GCEventViewController”. In the Language menu, choose Objective-C. Then, open the newly created header file and import the Game Controller framework.
If the game uses a storyboard,
to use a new view controller class derived from
. Alternatively, if the game creates a root view controller programmatically, then update the code to create an instance of a new subclass derived from

content.text: Show and hide the virtual controller

inlineContent.text: If there are no physical controllers connected, the game shows the virtual controller by default. If the player connects a physical controller, the game hides the virtual controller.
To show a virtual controller when there are no physical controllers connected, call
on it in the
(Swift) or
(Objective-C) handler.
When your game starts and there are no controllers connected, call
on the virtual controller to show it.
To hide the virtual controller when a player connects a physical controller, call disconnect on the virtual controller in the
(Swift) or

(Objective-C) handler. The game might receive a connection notification for a physical controller before receiving a notification for the virtual controller because controller connections are asynchronous.
When the player can’t perform certain actions in the game, hide the corresponding control elements using the
method. For example, during cutscene playback, the player can only press a button to skip playback.

code: // Only the X button is available when in a cutscene.

inlineContent.text: For better immersion and performance, the game can render a custom virtual controller instead of the default. Custom controls render symbols that represent their mapped actions rather than generic symbols.

When rendering custom touch controls, UIKit handles touch events and draws the results as part of the game’s user interface render pass. If your game is multithreaded, you need to pass data to your render thread in a thread-safe way because UIKit is only available on the main thread.
Set the hidden property to true when you create the
. Continue to set the
property because this affects the elements of the corresponding

code: // Add elements that your controller-handling code currently supports.

inlineContent.text: Add code to the implementation of
to install one or more
objects on the game’s view. For example, use a
to implement a direction pad or a
to implement a button. Set the view controller as the delegate and the target of each gesture recognizer, and store them in instance variables.
Then, declare an extension of the root view controller subclass that conforms to
. In the extension, declare the action methods that the configured gesture recognizers invoke.

code: // Declares an extension (unnamed category) of MyGameViewController.
// Place this declaration in the implementation file instead of the header file.

inlineContent.text: Implement the action methods to interpret the location of the touch, update the virtual controller, and inform the render thread.
Update your user interface from the main thread, instead of game controller code, to avoid unnecessary input latency.
Next, implement the
delegate method to define the bounds of the gesture recognizer. Calculate the bounding boxes of the controls based on the view’s current size, and place it within the view’s current safe area.

code: // Constrain the gesture recognizer to tracking one touch at any given time.

abstract.text: The base class for concrete gesture recognizers.
A set of methods implemented by the delegate of a gesture recognizer to fine-tune an app’s gesture-recognition behavior.
Asks the delegate if a gesture recognizer should receive an object representing a touch.
A continuous gesture recognizer that interprets long-press gestures.
A continuous gesture recognizer that interprets panning gestures.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
Called after the controller’s view is loaded into memory.
A notification that posts after a controller connects to the device.
A notification that posts after a controller disconnects from the device.
Support hardware game controllers in your game.
A representation of a real game controller, a virtual controller, or a snapshot of a controller.
A notification that posts after a controller connects to the device.
A notification that posts after a controller disconnects from the device.
A view controller that delivers input either from the responder chain to views, or from game controllers to profiles.
A software emulation of a real controller that you configure specifically for your game.
The configuration of a virtual controller.
The input elements of a virtual controller.
Connects the virtual controller to the device and displays it on the screen.
Changes the configuration for one of the virtual controller’s input elements.
